description.narrative: Economy-wide integration of Climate Change Adaptation to allow for increased integration of climate change adaptation and disaster risk management into national development planning and programming across all sectors.

Project Objective: 1. Increased capacity within GoS for coordination of cross-sectoral actions for climate change adaptation, including planning, budgeting, implementing and monitoring and evaluating. 2. Integration of climate change adaptation and DRM into the Strategy for the Development of Samoa 2017–2021.
Outcome 1.1: 1.1.1. Sector plans that include specific budgets for adaptation actions [adapted from AMAT 1.1.1] 1.1.2. Formulation and endorsement of National Climate Change Adaptation Strategy.
Outcome 1.2: 1.2.1. Increase in number of community-managed projects for adaptation to climate risks.
Outcome 2.1: 2.1.1. Number of people benefitting from improved flood management through implementation of hard and soft measures for protection of community assets. [AMAT 1.2.15]. 2.1.2. Number of people with increased income compared to the control group as a result of diversified livelihood practices and more secure access to livelihood assets, disaggregated by age and gender 2.1.3. Number of people adopting household-level processing facilities transferred to targeted groups disaggregated by age and gender [adapted from AMAT 3.1.1]
Outcome 2.2: 2.2.1. Number of villages covered by Village Disaster Risk Management plans to reduce risks of and respond to climate variability [adapted from AMAT 2.2.1]
Outcome 3.1: 3.1.1. Increased capacity of government staff to access information on climate and disaster risks as well as M&E on climate change adaptation.

comment.narrative:
Project Objective: 1. Capacity for national coordination of climate change adaptation and DRM is presently limited (Level 3: Partially developed capacity). 2. Integration of climate change adaptation and DRM in the Strategy for the Development of Samoa 2012–2016 is limited.
Outcome 1.1: 1.1.1. At present, 4 sector plans do not include climate change adaptation. 1.1.2. There is presently no National Climate Change Adaptation Strategy.
Outcome 1.2: 1.2.1. Few community-managed projects for adaptation to climate risks. 1.2.2. No monitoring of public expenditure on climate change adaptation.
Outcome 2.1: 2.1.1. No people benefit from improved flood management from climate-resilient flood protection measures introduced in Vaisigano River catchment for protection of community assets. 2.1.2. No difference in income between targeted and control groups owing to diversified livelihoods and secure access to livelihood assets. 2.1.3. No people have adopted and utilised household-level processing facilities to support diversified livelihoods
Outcome 2.2: 2.2.1. No Village Disaster Risk Management Plans implemented by the project.
Outcome 3.1: 3.1.1. Low capacity of government staff to access information on climate and disaster risks as well as M&E on climate change adaptation.

Project Objective: 1. By end of project, GoS will have sufficient capacity for effective coordination of cross-sectoral actions for CCA (Level5:fully developed 2. The Strategy for the Development of Samoa 2017–2021 will include key performance indicators for climate change adaptation for outcomes relating to agriculture, community development, water and sanitation, transport and climate and disaster resilience.
Outcome 1.1 1.1.1. All 15 sector plans are formulated to include climate change adaptation and are approved by the end of the project. 1.1.2. A National Climate Change Adaptation Strategy is formulated and endorsed by the end of the project.
Outcome 1.2 1.2.1. At least 20 community-managed projects for adaptation to climate risks. 1.2.2. MoF-CRICU and MNRE-CCU have improved capacity to monitor expenditure on climate change adaptation.
Outcome 2.12.1.1. At least 12,000 people benefit from improved flood management from climate-resilient flood protection measures introduced in Vaisigano River catchment for protection of community assets (6,000 male and 6,000 female). 2.1.2. At least 600 beneficiaries adopting diversified livelihoods have demonstrable increases in income compared to the control group owing to more secure access to livelihood assets (at least 400 women irrespective of age and 200 youth irrespective of gender). 2.1.3. At least 600 beneficiaries participating in project interventions adopt and utilise household-level processing facilities to support diversified livelihoods (at least 400 women irrespective of age and at least 200 youth irrespective of gender).
Outcome 2.2 2.2.1. At least 100 Village Disaster Risk Management Plans implemented by the project.
Outcome 3.1 3.1.1. By the end of the project, key officials from MNRE-CCU and MoF-CRICU will have sufficient capacity for accessing information on climate and disaster risks as well as M&E on climate change adaptation (Level 5: Fully developed capacity)

1. There is continuous coordination through the TAG quarterly meetings, meeting of the National Climate Resilience Steering Committee (NSC), which is the decision making body chaired by Ministry of Finance(MoF) and coordinated by the MoF-CRICD for projects namely; LDCF EWACC, PREP and the GCF VCP. Reporting of progress from EWACC are also reported to these meetings as well as the National Environment Sector Coordination Committee and Cabinet Development Committee. There have been four TAG meetings held within 2020 to monitor progress and guide implementation of the project. GEF and Climate Change Division established in MNRE. 2. The integration of climate change and disaster risk management have been incorporated into the existing SDS 2017-2021. Key performance indicators in sectors and budget for climate change adaptation for outcomes relating to agriculture, community development, water and sanitation, transport, environmental, health as well as climate and disaster resilience are noted as key priority areas and M&E Framework of the current SDS.
Outcome 1.1 1.1.1.With the integration into the SDS 2016/17 and 2017/2021, incorporated specific CCA/DRM actions and budgets under Key Outcome 13 to improve CC and Disaster planning 1.1.2. Climate Change Policy 2020 endorsed by cabinet
Outcome 1.2 1.2.1. project target achieved 1.2.2. Within the duration of the project the Climate Change and GEF Division has been established in MNRE and similar the Climate Resilience Investment and resilience Division in MOF. Both Division continue to improve capture and reporting of CCA expenditure through the various mechanisms such as reporting the Climate Resilience Steering Committee, the Cabinet Development Committee and SDS M&E framework.
Outcome 2.1 2.1.1. Integrated Watershed Management Plan completed. The construction of the river protection wall along segment 1 of the Vaisigano river was completed in January 2019. More than 12,000 beneficiaries from the Greater Apia Areas (Gasegase, Fuluasou and Loimata o Apaula rivers) have benefitted from improved flood management through the deepening of river channels. Further studies are planned for the above-mentioned rivers. 2.1.2. More than 640 (384:256 ratio female to males inclusive of PWD) beneficiaries have benefited from project support with diversified livelihoods and increased income generation activities. Monitoring visits to follow up on progress of project interventions 2.1.3. 80 vulnerable families under this programme engaged in household level micro-enterprises such as vegetable garden, canteens, bakeries, handmade printing, plantations, mixed cropping and small scale fisheries.
Outcome 2.2 2.2.1. Cumulative progress of 21 CDCRM plans. This activity has been delayed in 2020 due to lead agency DMO supporting the COVID-19 SOE activities. 82 villages are included in the CDCRM programme
Outcome 3.1 3.1.1. the project provides regular updates and reports for accumulating information on the database within MNRE on climate adaptation work by the next reporting period. Continuous capacity building of staff and contribution to divisional outputs provides enhanced knowledge to access and provide M&E to information on Climate and Disaster Risk Management. The key officials from MNRE-CCU and MoF-CRICU will have sufficient capacity for accessing information on climate and disaster risks as well as M&E on climate change adaptation (Level 5: Fully developed capacity) as continuous discussions and deliberations are conducted I Technical Advisory Group meetings not only for EWACC but other related climate change projects

Project Objective: 1. There is continuous quarterly meetings for the National Climate Resilience Steering Committee (NSC), which is the decision making body chaired by Ministry of Finance(MoF) and coordinated by the Climate Resilience Investment and Coordination Division (MoF-CRICD) for projects namely; LDCF EWACC, Pacific Programme on Climate Resilience, PREP and the GCF Vaisigano Catchment Project. Reporting of progress from EWACC are also reported to these meetings. There have been four (4) Technical Advisory group meetings (TAG) held within 2018 to monitor progress and guide implementation of the project. 2. The integration of climate change and disaster risk management have been incorporated into the existing SDS 2017-2021. Key performance indicators in sectors and budget for climate change adaptation for outcomes relating to agriculture, community development, water and sanitation, transport, environmental, health as well as climate and disaster resilience are noted as key priority areas and M&E Framework of the current SDS.
Outcome 1.1 1.1.1. With the integration into the SDS 2017-2021, the majority of sector plans have incorporated specific climate change adaptation actions and budgets. 1.1.2. This is in the pipeline of activities to commence in the remaining timeframe of this project and is one of the key product of project officer for climate change policy to be recruited.
Outcome 1.2 1.2.1. As stakeholders of the Technical Advisory Group, continuous information sharing and update of project implementation is shared within this forum. Community engagement through implementation of activities towards livelihood improvement whether it be communities or household is an approach that the project is heading towards through encouraging youth and women entrepreneurship as well as roll out of Community Disaster and Climate Risk Management to increase knowledge of adaptation and improving resilience to climate change risks.
35 families have been included in the improvement of livelihood component. Only 1 village has completed the CDCRM with 2 in the MoU.
1.2.2. Also, within this outcome, the development and review of the National Building Code for Samoa emphasis the significance of integrating the building of assets that are climate resilient gain. This is a national standard towards buildings.
Outcome 2.1 2.1.1. The construction of the Vaisigano flood protection wall for segment 1 has been implemented within this reporting period and estimated target is achieved with the number of households or beneficiaries benefitting from this flood protection infrastructure. 2.1.2. This is the direction in the number of beneficiaries currently been awarded start your own business initiative. This is part of activities implemented with the MWCSD, METI and also CDCRM roll out once the Samoa Red Cross are on board in the next reporting year to undertake the roll out of CDCRM. Households and families have shown increase in income generation as part of the work under the project for the improving of livelihoods. From individual businesses ,targeting women and youth, whom have been trained and have setup their businesses which include, vegetation, farming, canteen, handicrafts and the likes are all interventions provided through the project to encompass the improving of livelihoods for these families. 2.1.3. Through this reporting period a feasibility study was undertaken for the proposed small business incubator which is envisaged to nurture business as an initiative under the MWCSD under this project. Throughout this reporting period, training undertaken by the Small Business Enterprises Centre as well as preparing business plans for the selected individuals of 35 families with 8 members per family is estimated beneficiaries from these initiatives. Work with an NGO,s namely;METI has also been driven under this project throughout this reporting period with their Taiala programmes and healthy living which promotes kitchen gardens and seed savings to encourage women within families to promote sustainable farming activities to improve livelihoods has also been one of the key achievements of this outcome.
Outcome 2.2 2.2.1. This component is in the pipeline of activities to be undertaken in the next reporting period. The household survey and data management system is in place. Published materials and training on the database have been completed throughout this period. The MoU with Samoa Red Cross Society has been finalised and this NGO together with DMO and PMU will roll out the development of the CDCRM to selected villages within the time frame of the project.
Outcome 3.1 3.1.1. The midterm review of the project was undertaken within this reporting period and progress of the project with ongoing TAG meetings to follow up on the development and progress of the project.
